text: [Music]
my first topic of the evening is um one
of my all-time favorite techniques for
dealing with large scale software
complexity and that's uh feature Flags
now you may have heard of feature Flags
under other names they're sometimes
called switches are sometimes called
feature flippers but generally the the
concept is exactly the same and in my
opinion this is one of the highest R Roi
items that you can add to a code base um
we built when we built these for lanyard
it took an afternoon to put in a basic
mechanism for this and we used it every
day from then on and it gave us an
enormous amount of value so really what
you're trying to get out anytime you're
trying to build high quality software is
you want to to obey the mant of
releasing early and releasing often
until your software is in front of of
real human beings you have absolutely no
idea how they're going to use it if you
if you're or if you're even building the
right thing this um has been further and
further popularized by The Lean Startup
movement which um I I stole this image
from their website they have this sort
of cycle where you come up with an idea
and then you build it to create the
product then you measure how people are
using the product you take the data from
that you use that to generate more ideas
and really the goal of any startup
especially if you've got a limited
Runway is to race around that cycle as
quickly as possible make sure you're
building the right thing now if you want
to build things if you want to iterate
quickly if you want to build things um
build things fast um when it's just you
and a green field development and a text
editor that's pretty easy you can knock
out features very quickly um but what we
found with es um so we experienced this
firsthand with lanyard as your product
grows and as your development team grows
it gets much harder to build features
and and and ship them um as uh one thing
we found in particular is every time you
release a new feature you have to think
about the way it interacts with all of
your previous features so if it's your
first feature that's really easy but um
later on in the development of lanyard
we released a feature called guides
which allowed users to collect together
a set of events as like my top python
events of 2014 um and when we built that
feature we realized that before we
released it we had to figure out what
that was going to look like on the users
page and on the event pages and how it
would work on our topic pages and how it
would interact with our mobile apps and
every single feature we' released
previously was interacting with the new
thing we were building so feature
development takes a lot longer it's a
lot longer to get it right there's a
there's a lot more complexity involved
it's tempting when you're faced with
this situation to use branches to build
a branch per feature spend spend a bunch
of time in that branch and then merge it
in when you're done but long-term
branches have a whole bunch of their own
problems you find yourself um totally
diverging the functionality of the main
site um you're not your your new code
isn't getting tested properly and
generally your you you set yourself up
for all kinds of complexity at the last
moment when you merge it back in and
find out that there are conflicts and
and and feature interactions that you
havn't expected so the alternative to
this is to use feature flags and um most
companies that use feature Flags
actually tend to work in the in in a
single main development Branch they'll
Spike off little feature branches for
very short periods of time but but but
the the aim is always to merge the new
features into the branch as quickly as
possible because what feature Flags let
you do is they allow you to expose
features on your site to a subset of
your user base and at first that might
just be your you yourself or your or the
rest of your development team you can
then roll the feature out to Alpha
testers onto beta testers onto trusted
customers and eventually release it to
your entire audience um and this has a
whole bunch of advantages including um
one in particular which is it means you
can decouple the deployment of a feature
from the release of that feature you
don't find yourself shipping a new
feature and sshing or pushing code up to
all of your servers at once crossing
your fingers and hoping it all works you
can deploy the feature several days
beforehand and then just turn it on when
you're ready to put out your press
release or or do whatever you it is you
do to to release something it also gives
you R risk-free instant roll back if you
turn the feat flag on and stuff breaks
you could just turn it back off
again so I'll talk you through a couple
of implementations of feature Flags um
I'll talk about how we did them at
lanyard where we essentially rolled our
own from scratch as a very simple system
and then I'll explain how Eventbrite
does something quite a bit more comp
comprehensive using an open source
solution so at lanyard we had feature
flags for all sorts of things but
fundamentally each one was a identifier
which is designed to be referenced from
code and then a human readable
description so we could tell what the
thing was meant to do so we had a
setting with all of our feature Flags in
it and then we store the feature Flags
in the database um there's not going to
be a great deal of code in this
presentation but uh I figure everyone
here probably knows what ajango model
looks like so in a this is a Jango model
for a future flag it has a unique slug
which is that short string it has a
description and it's got a Boolean field
saying if it's been switched on for all
of the users of the site or not um then
we also have a many to many field
against users so we can select zero or
more users that the flag should be
enabled for and we have the same thing
against groups so we can turn on the
flag for an entire group of users and
then the remainder of the implementation
is one method that given a user tells
you if the feature flag is enabled or or
not so if each flag is turned on if it's
turned on for everyone or if it's turned
on for the specific user or if it's
turned on for one of the groups that
that user is a member of Believe It or
Not that was pretty much this was pretty
much the entirety of our initial feature
flag implementation um over time we
evolved it a fair bit we added caching
um to make sure that it wasn't going to
completely clobber our database and we
added quite a few helper methods to make
it really easy in code to use these
flags um this is our first helper method
this is a view Decora you can stick it
on any view function that makes up your
website and all it says is that this
view function is only available if the
user has the topic tracking feature flag
um if they don't we serve a 404 error
because we don't want people guessing
URLs and sniffing around on a website
trying to figure out what we were going
to uh release next um we have a method
on user saying if user has flag topic
tracking and then you can have code
levels switching between the featured
version and non-featured version and we
also added feature Flags into our
template language we had a custom tag um
where you can say if the new event right
flag is on this is actually the feature
flag we used when we announced the
acquisition because we wanted to make
sure that we put the press relas out and
then the um an Eventbrite company logo
appeared all over the site
simultaneously so we could flip on a
flag and and add that into our footer um
this we did add one more feature um one
more template flag because we found that
we had a this we had a whole bunch of
trusted Alpha and beta testers but we
turn on features for them and sometimes
they wouldn't they wouldn't have read
the email saying this was a test feature
and they get excited and start tweeting
screenshots of something that we weren't
ready to release yet so the flag active
template tags means if the feat if the
user has access to the login with
Facebook feature and it's not turned on
for every user display in this case a
little Alpha only message so they know
not to get too excited and start
tweeting
already um one very useful feature flag
that we built quite early on which which
served us really well was a feature flag
for putting the entire site into readon
mode and this is it turns out it's
incredibly useful if you're working with
a decent sized code base because it get
means that you can pretty much freeze
the freeze your site in time do a whole
bunch of maintenance maintenance
activities behind the scenes and then
unfreeze it without ever having to take
the site down and Andrew will be talking
um later on about a trick that we uh
quite quite a big trick that we pulled
off with this so readon mode you turn
the feature flag on a couple of things
happen you get this yellow Banner on
every page on the site and the login
button disappears and we also um our
authentication middleware actually
starts ignoring your login cookie so
even if you'd logged in already will
ignore the cookie and pretend that
you're logged out in Lan yard's case you
cannot make any modifications s you
can't do anything that triggers a right
if you're not logged in so by just
forcing the user into logged out mode
they were unable to make any changes and
we could guarantee that the site would
stay in readon mode um likewise our
mobile API started ignoring or tokens so
the mobile apps behaved like the user
was logged out as well while the while
while you're in the state you can do all
sorts of things you can clone the
database do all sorts of things to the
database switch over from one cluster to
another you can do quite wide ranging um
maintenance tasks and in fact Andrew
later will be describing how we move
from MySQL running on ec2 to postgres
running on softlay um with I think 20
minutes of readon mode and no downtime
at all so you can pull off some pretty
neat tricks with with with again just a
simp simple feature flag um now
eventbrite's approach to feature Flags
is quite different um Eventbrite uses a
piece of open software called gargoyle
which was released by the team at discus
the online commenting um the online
commenting system and unfortunately with
all of the stuff it's quite hard to find
decent screenshots but this one um
demonstrates that discus has switches
and it has and you can set up a whole
bunch of different properties on those
switches so rather than just saying this
feature flag is available for this user
you can say um and in fact these are all
examples of things of EMP do you can say
this feature is available to any you to
these specific users or anyone who's a
member of Staff um this feature flag is
controls um this is only turned on for
these particular events so it's an event
related feature or these organizers we
use it in our API so we can turn on
specific API endpoints for specific API
Keys um we can feature Flag by country
based on IP address so if you're in
Germany you get some some subtle variant
in behavior um and we we also we can
even use it for those tlds that Nathan
was talking about and to show you how
flexible gargo can be and that
flexibility does come at a cost this is
the entire implementation of a rule set
saying okay we want to be able to set
conditions on a switch based on your
country and all you have to do in gargo
is subass condition set give it a
storage string so you can store the
country that you care about um it can
execute method that says I I I I can be
um this condition can be applied if you
have an HTTP request uh and then you
have a get field value that says if the
field is Country Return the country
attribute from the request which is
previously populated by a piece of
middleware you register that and
straight away you can start assigning
rules to individual feature Flags where
you say if the country is Germany this
flag should be
enabled there are a whole bunch of
gotchas if you're working with feature
Flags um one of the most important to
test against is looking out for
unexpected flag combinations um it's
quite given the amount of code that you
can end up feature um end up hiding
behind feature Flags there's always a
chance that two feature flag
combinations you hadn't thought of might
lead to weird Behavior so generally it's
a good idea to try and keep the things
that are affected by feature flags are
separate as possible and if they are
going to overlap make sure that you QA
things thoroughly before you before you
release them um old feature flag code
can get really ugly these each each of
these things individually it's you know
it's an if this do that else do this
it's very it's relative easy to to read
but over time as you accumulate more
feature Flags your codebase can grow
huge numbers of branches so um it's very
important once say feature is live and
you're sure it's going to stay live that
you strip out all of the feature flag
code for that um and that you know
that's that's just generally good
practice and then the last one of course
is performance where if you think about
it anytime somebody requests a page of
your website you're doing a whole bunch
of these feature flag checks and so you
can end up doing if you're not careful
you'll end up doing a few like three or
for database queries per page view on
your site um gargoyle has a few things
in place to help with performance it's
um quite aggressive with caching it'll
cach things in local memory in the
python process for up to 30 seconds
it'll fall back on external cache after
that but even with all of those caching
layers we found that at Eventbrite scale
a huge amount of our Network traffic our
internal Network traffic was straight up
mcache calls to load um feature Flags
out of the out of the cache so we ended
up putting a me a small mcash instance
on every front-end web server just to
host a copy of the feature Flags so at
least that Network traffic was was on
the local box and wasn't going out over
the
network um turns out a lot of companies
use feature Flags this is quite
interesting this is um the only
screenshot I could find of Facebook's
feature flag mechanism which is called
gatekeeper and apparently allows I think
they've extended even more that now they
can flag features to people who've liked
a certain thing or who are employees or
have a certain browser or a certain age
or shoe size or goodness knows what else
and back in 2012 um let's just cut off
there they were doing over 500 million
gatekeeper checks a second and that was
a couple of years ago so you can imagine
that they're doing way more than that
now so this kind of this quite neatly
illustrates that you can scale feature
Flags to to any scale that you like if
you're if you're if you're sensible
about the way you architect them so
feature Flags once you have them in
place they're kind of a Swiss army knife
they become something that you end up
hanging all sorts of other functional
functionality off um at lanyard we use
them to turn on features for our for
some of our paying customers so you you
know we we didn't even need a payment
system for this initially we could
invoice someone they paid us we flipped
on a feature flag and they got extra
capabilities for their events and at
vent bite we've actually been building
an entire AB testing framework on top of
our existing feature flag mechanisms so
once you have the this relatively thin
abstraction there's a whole bunch of
interesting stuff you can start building
with it so
really the the takeaways from this are
you should use feature Flags if you're
building pretty much anything at all
it's worth getting feature Flags in
there early on and starting to lean on
them don't use long lived branches go
with get get your code into core and use
feature Flags to turn it on and off the
ROI on them as a feature is pretty
ridiculous the amount of effort taken to
get them up and running is Tiny and you
will derive enormous value in terms of
improved iteration speed ability an
ability to just get code in front of
human beings and if you are going to get
going to going to implement them
gargoyle is a pretty decent Standalone
open source package which will get you
up and running very quickly or if you
decide to roll your own it's really not
a very complicated thing to build and it
